# Topics we covered
On September 7-8th, [RailsGirls PDX](http://railsgirls.com/portland) happened so women could learn about Ruby on Rails and meet other women interested in doing the same.  Even though we only had a an evening and a day to introduce you to Rails, we talked about a lot of different things.  Hopefully the stuff found below will be helpful as you continue to learn about Ruby on Rails and developing web applications!

This recap doesn't cover installing Rails, since after the event, you should already have it installed.  I've linked liberally to a site called [Skillcrush](http://skillcrush.com/), which defines tech terms using non-technical language.

## Tools
Before getting started on our first Rails app, there are a few tools with which we need to be familiar
* [Command Prompt](https://github.com/lkemmerer/railsgirlspdx-recap/wiki/Command-Prompt)
  * The command prompt is a text-only program that allows you to interact with your operating system. We use it to go to different places (directories) on your hard drive, to start our Rails web server, and to run other commands.  
[Learn More...](https://github.com/lkemmerer/railsgirlspdx-recap/wiki/Command-Prompt)

* [Text editor](https://github.com/lkemmerer/railsgirlspdx-recap/wiki/Text-Editor)
  * A text editor is a text editing program, similar to Microsoft Word, but for code. -- [Skillcrush](http://skillcrush.com/2012/09/10/text-editor/)   
[Learn More...](https://github.com/lkemmerer/railsgirlspdx-recap/wiki/Text-Editor)

* Web Browser
  * Chrome, Firefox, and Internet Explorer are all web browsers.  When you run `rails s`, this is where you'll go to see your app!

## Concepts
* Ruby
* Gems
* Ruby on Rails
* Models, Views, and Controllers

## Do stuff!
* Creating a new Rails app
* Generating a Scaffold for Blog Entry functionality
* Adding a new Gem (twitter-bootstrap-rails
* Modifying your views

## Topics we mentioned
* Renaming your app
* JSON and Hashes
* Sending emails with Rails
